title: ‘Feel half alive’: survivor of Australia’s mushroom murders mourns 2 years later
description: Erin Patterson attended court in person for the two-day pre-sentencing hearing, set aside for victims’ impact statements.
content:
The only guest to survive a toxic mushroom lunch with murderer said on Monday he felt “half alive” without his wife, who was one of the three victims.

Pastor Ian Wilkinson wept in court as he spoke of the loss of his wife, Heather, after she ate a beef Wellington dish laced with death cap mushrooms – the world’s deadliest fungi.

Patterson, 50, was convicted last month of serving the poisonous fare to her husband’s parents, aunt and uncle at a sumptuous lunch in her rural home in the state of Victoria in 2023.

Within days, the parents and aunt were dead, but the uncle – Ian Wilkinson – survived after weeks in hospital to give testimony at his host’s murder trial, which became a global media sensation.

Patterson was present in the Supreme Court of Victoria in Melbourne for the two-day hearing, set aside for relatives to testify to the impact of her crimes and for lawyers to argue over the severity of her sentencing.
summary: The only guest to survive a toxic mushroom lunch with murderer, Paul Patterson, said he felt "half alive" without his wife, Heather. Patterson was convicted last month of serving the food laced with death cap mushrooms at her home in Perth, Australia. The only survivor of the event was Ian Wilkinson, who survived after spending weeks in hospital.
shortSummary: The survivor of the Smiths murder, Ian Wilkinson, expressed his sorrow over his wife's death after she ate a toxic mushroom, recalling a life-long struggle.
